												Even if Spore wasn't as it was expected to be like at launch, it is still a great game to play.Games like Spore don't come around often. I have never seen another game with so much freedom on what you can do inside of it. In the Cell Stage, you get to choose whether you are an omnivore, a carnivore or a herbivore. It's an extremely specific detail and it's why this game is so well made. There are many small choices like this in the game, you can become a warrior and kill everyone or trade your way up the ranks or just be a friendly race.The Cell Stage is the first stage that you play in the game, where you must start as a small cell and work your way up to becoming a creature with legs and arms that can walk around on land. The first cruical choice in this game is deciding whether you are a carnivore, an omnivore or a herbivore. This decision can effect your abilities in the creature stage. After you have chosen, you must either eat red meat (carnivore) or green plants (herbivore) or both if you are an omnivore. The general basis of this stage is to just eat as much as you can, and eventually you will become bigger and bigger, and it roughly takes about 10 minutes to finish this stage.The second stage in the game, The Creature Stage is one of the longest stages in the game. After finishing the cell stage, you must ally or kill other creatures until your brain becomes smart enough to create fire. This stage may take a while, and it all depends on how quickly you adapt to your surroundings and when you get certain unlocks. Overall this stage is very fun and can vary depending on what choices you make. The Tribal Stage is the third stage in this game, and starts after you get a cutscene of your creatures learning to make fire. This stage requires you to build huts for playing music to other tribes (allying them) or building huts to equip your tribe members with weapons to destory your opposing tribes with. This stage is definitely the most stressful stage of them all, as some of the timing with the instruments are off and can purely be based on luck in some cases. Fighting with other tribes is more fun and feels more rewarding.The second-to-last stage in this game is the Civillization Stage. In this stage, you are either preset to Religious, Economic or Millitary, depending on your previous actions in the Tribal and Creature stage. (You can manually set these if you decide to start a game at this stage.) Religious and Millitary cities have the same sort of way to gaining control of other cities, which is by attacking them. This is normally the quickest way to do the stage but can take some time if you do not decide to use the weapons provided at the near-end game on the toolbar. Economic cities, however, can propose to other cities to trade with them, which can generate you and the city you are trading with Sporebucks, and can be beneficial in the future. You gain control of the cities by buying them. The last stage in the game and the most fun and definitely the most time consuming. This stage starts after you conquer all the cities in the Civilization Stage. The stage starts out by having you learn the basic controls for your spaceship, scanning a crashed spaceship and a destroyed civilization. The end goal of this stage is just to get to the middle of the galaxy. However, you can do many other things in this stage, such as painting planets, searching for artifacts and trading with other empires.There is not really a story or plot to this game, as the story is mainly up to you and what you want to do. There is only a small plot point and it only features at the end of the game, once you go into the center of the galaxy. The creation menu in this game is very unique, there are many parts that you can use to create your own buildings, spaceships, creatures and vehicles. You can even paint different colours onto your creations and make them stand out however you want, whether it is with big or small horns, or with a big mouth and small eyes, the possibilities that this game shows is endless and very enjoyable to use.An add-on to the original game is called [Spore] Galactic Adventures, which expands your journey as an empire and lets you go down onto planets and do missions like hunting for artifacts or helping in a fight. You captain your own ship, like you do in the original game, but you can also have three crew members, just like in the creature stage, that can accompany you in your missions. The DLC also goes more indepth on what class / traits you can have, and can manually choose if you want to be a Trader, a Zealot or a Ecnomist, through the points that you earn by doing missions, you can select tools that can help you in that specific section, such as deadly weapons for the warrior and better energy storage for the scientist. Galactic Adventures is a great example of what a DLC should be. It's fun, increases the gameplay and gives you more freedom in your world.TL:DR This game is absolutely worth getting. It is so good and well-created in lots of places and gives you enough choices and decisions in the game to make it feel like it matters. The best thing about this game is definitely the space stage and the Galactic Adventures addon because it gives a fresh feel to the game and gives it a better sense of realism.

												Well, plenty have done reviews over the basics of the previous Spore games, so why don't I review the extension: Galatic Adventures.This is played in conjunction with Spore's Space Stage as "Missions". Galactic Adventures actually starts you off with a few easy Maxis-made Adventures, where you get the hang of how each adventure plays out. These can range from action-themed adventures, puzzle-solving adventures, story/quest adventures, and so on. Galactic Adventures even has an Adventure Creator, where you can make your OWN Adventures for you to play AND to share with players, worldwide, on the Sporepedia. This also adds a new list of unique buildings, vehicles, and creatures to work with (all tagged with "gaprop"), and you can create your own, too, and tag them with "gaprop" so you don't happen to get these individual creations in your Space Stage gameplay (or you don't have to). Also, along with the adventures, each game file creates its own Captain (your creature in the Space Stage), which you can name and outfit with Captain Parts (weapons, sheilds, life/energy storage, social parts, etc), to further make each exploration (and adventure) unique.At this point, you may spend a lot of time either downloading new adventures, or making your own; and at that point, the only real limit is your imagination.Live long and prosper! Nanoo Nanoo!Update: For those wondering what have I done for 2K + hours in Spore: Making playable adventures, and alpha and beta-testing them.

												(I had to post this review on the Galactic Adventures page because I play it with this pack, but this review talks about the core game.)I have had this game since 2008 as a retail copy, so I have put more hours into it then it shows on here. I love this game, despite it's flaws, it's quirky, it's unique and it let's me get creative! I understand that this game was overhyped as hell back in the early 2000s, but playing it for what it is, it's still a fun game. In fact, it's not really bad, just was disappointing to many. So now I will quickly go over the game and it's features it has to offer.GameplayCell stageIt's a nice tutorial for the game that helps you understand what Spore is all about, which is surviving in a harsh environment and helping your creature evolve. The only thing that bothers me about this stage of the game, is that there is no procedural user generated content to find...it's just Maxis's creations.Creature stageOne of my favorite stages, your cell now has evolved onto land and now has to make a choice...dance or kill. You're now surviving in a much larger world from cell stage, you must either make allies or enemies with your new neighbors. Doing this will provide you DNA points (which is used as currency in the creature creator) and body parts. Gaining new parts and DNA will help you change your generation and give you social and combat skills in order to defend or befriend other more advanced creatures as you get farther into the stage.Tribal stageMy other favorite stage, this one is more of a simplified RTS style stage. Your species is now sentient and has formed a tribe. You now control a group of your species instead of just one. Once again, you must decide on whether to make friends or enemies with other tribes. You collect resources (which is food) and use it as currency to build tools for your tribe, to give as a gift to hostile tribes which you can become friends with then or give to wild animals and make them your pets, the pets can help defend you and they give you eggs which is also used as a resource. One thing I will criticize about this stage is that it's a little too similar to creature stage and the npc tribes don't interact with each other.Civilization stageThis is where your species becomes the dominate species on your planet, they now build cities and vehicles which you can create! Depending how you played the previous stage will determine what kind of city and vehicle you'll get. There is religious, economic and military. They work similar but with a different goal in mind, as a military you'll conquer other cities, as a religious you'll convert cities and as an economic you'll buy cities. You'll be able to use land, sea and air vehicles which will determine the best way to dominate other cities. Some cities can only be reached by sea or air vehicles.Space stageI haven't fully explored space stage but here's what I know of it, Space stage is the meat of the game, it's a combination of all of the other stages, you'll be able to create your first spaceship and explore a galaxy of millions and I mean,literally millions of stars. Think of it as a scaled down No Man's Sky. Your able to travel to other solar systems, trade with other races, start wars with them or form an alliance with them. Take on missions (this is expanded on with Galactic Adventures expansion pack), colonize planets, find rare collectibles, abduct creatures and manipulate other planets by terraforming them or destroy them. The main goal of the space stage is to get to the center of the galaxy. However, the game will not stop there, once you reach the main goal, you are still able to freely explore the Galaxy to you hearts content. There is a lot to do that you could spend hours on this stage.EditorsThere are a few editors throughout the main game that allows you to create any kind of creature, vehicle, building and spaceship. They are quite possibly the best thing this game has to offer! They are incredibly robust and flexible and most importantly...easy to use! You can create a six legged horse with dragon wings! Or a large tank with twenty guns and wheels!  Or your favorite character as a spaceship! The possibilities are endless! I have spent so many hours creating all sorts of abstract things.Procedural user generated contentAnother cool feature of this game is that all of the npcs such as creatures, vehicles, buildings and spaceships are all made by other players. You will be able to see your friends creations in your game! There is a handy content browser called Sporepedia, that lets you share, browse and download other creations right into your game.So yes, despite the negative reception the game got years ago, I think it's a fun game. I only wish that Maxis would update the game again, I want to be able to make plants, to give more variety to the planets.

												I'll review each segment of the game seperately...Base Game: This game takes you with creating your own, unique alien race and having them progress from the cellular level all the way through civilization and finally to space travel, and exploring the cosmos!There is a lovely "Karma" system where your actions, whether warlike, peaceful, or inbetween will set the special abilities, and stance of your civilization as it progresses.You'll see many types of games set into the different stages, and the game is overall fun to play.Cell Stage: A top-down cellular fight to the finish. With fun evolution mechanics, moments of truly feeling small, and the race for survival. This is one of the best stages.Creature Stage: You've left the ocean, and are given free reign to explore the planet! This mode is immensely fun as well. You have a small group of your own species and you go from nest to nest making friends, and EATING OTHERS!You'll encounter random epic beasts, sudden space ships and meteor showers!A wonderful stage overall!Tribal Stage: One of my least favorite stages if only for the dullness. While I understand it can be fun to have an RTS "Go destroy their tribe!" deal, I find this part bores me, and I just get through really quickly just so I can get to the next stage.Civilization Stage: OHho! Do you love Civilization? Do you love RTS games? Do you enjoy fighting 8 enemies at once all vying for the same planet!? THEN DO I HAVE A STAGE FOR YOU!Mattering on how you've progressed, you're either a warmongering fighter with tanks, planes, and boats of mass destruction, a financial empire that's trying to buy out their enemies, or a religious zealotry trying to convert everyone!This gamemode is amazing fun, and is really a better step-up from the Tribal stage.Also, I love that the final ability for a Warmongering race is a mass of Nuclear Missles being launched at once.Space Stage: You've done it! You have progressed your species far enough that they've banded together to create a spacecraft that will explore the cosmos! You go about spreading your species through  colonization pods, buying out other speicies systems, or completley annhilating them to make room for your own. Galactic Adventures has you take the captain of your Space Stage ship and go on user-created adventures that will level them up. These really help add more content and increase the value and playtime of the game.

												 DISCLAIMER: IF YOU WON'T READ THIS, AT LEAST READ THE TL;DR AT THE END, IT'S ONLY A LINE LONG. THANK YOU.SPORE is an impressive game. In this game, you start out as a tiny cell (which really resembles zooplankton), where you eat plants or other cells/floating meat. You can call a mate and get to the cell editor, where you can create ANYTHING you can imagine. You evolve into a creature. This is easily the best stage. You can socialize with other species, or kill their faces. You can meet rogue and Epic creatures, supersized versions of regulars. You can add rogues and regular creatures to a pack, but Epics are off limits. You evolve into a tribe. This stage, and the civ stage are not so good, but still acceptable.The Galactic God of sorts, (you), command the tribe. You can ally or kill off the tribes, as before. Civ stage. You capture "spice geysers", which produce "sporebucks", or "spucks". The sign for spucks are the same as the Simoleons, so Sims players may relate to that.  You can be religious, attacking civs with the Ways of Spode, military, which just nukes, or any other violent way to kill. Kinda in the middle are the ecomonists. They'll buy cities for big spucks, so that's always nice. After taking all 12 cities on the world, you evolve into the Space Stage! From here, you command your own ship, and with the GA expanison, you command your captain too. Beam down onto planets, infiltrate, prevent wars, stop invasions, you do it all! Your main goal is to reach the center of the galaxy, but around you is the imposing Grox Empire. They span 4000 systems, and kill you on sight. You can ally with them, which is dancing with the Devil. Everyone hates the Grox. They'll all declare war if you ally them, unless you have 200+ relationship points, which are bought with gifts, missions, trading, routes, etc.That's all for the main concept. Now, for a little bit on Sporecasts and possibilities. Sporecasts are you, the user, and other's creations. Of course, you can just make critters, but there's millions of awesome creatures made and ready to play! Maxis made their share of critters, just to ensure no one runs out of little dudes. That's all for now. tl;dr: good game, good content, best bought when on a discount. do get the main SPORE game first, as galactic adventures is not usable without it.

												Galactic Adventures adds missions for your space captain during the final stage of Spore. Previously during this stage you were mostly restricted to being a spaceship - which is kinda weird when you've spent so much time careful crafting the creatures that you're playing with and this was meant to address that.On the plus side, it is nice to be able to play your creatures again and it does even potentially give you the ability to earn the super powers from the other factions (for example you could be militarily based, but earn a shaman super power) rather than just being restricted to one and some of the missions are kinda fun, although there is often a quite heavy focus on combat which is still not great and you don't have any equips for initially.The down side though... It was a bit of a half arsed attempted by Maxis to cash in on user content and the amount of missions actually included with it by default seems to be rather small. Places will send you off to do a mission and when you arrive there you'll find it's a mission you have already played. Now at this point you can only progress by completing it again, but because you've already done it once you won't receive any experience for it. This won't stop other planets sending you on this mission again and again though. Player created content is frequently dross and the filtering system is largely unintuitive making it very hard to make sure you actually get any decent adventures.Each adventure also eats a planet. Did that planet have an expensive spice on it? Too bad. Is it contantly sending out signals to tell you there is a rare hidden there? Too bad. Once it's an adventure mission, even if it's a duplicate, it will sit there cutting off access to that planet forever. Since planets tend to generate them in nearby systems this can result in areas, especially around your starting systems becoming cluttered with unusable mission planets.Galactic Adventures is a great idea that was badly implemented and promptly dropped by the studio rather than being fixed. Whilst it definitely adds some much needed creature time to the space stage I don't feel it adds enough longevity to actually be worth it. If you already have Spore, pick it up during a sale if it goes decently low.

												You don't need Spore to play this, just buy this one since it's cheaper and includes the origional Spore as well as aditional content. This game starts out as Feeding Frenzy, then it quickly turns into an RPG where your species must either befriend or destroy many enemies, then you evolve into a tribal species where the game plays like an RTS, where you must kill or befriend other species that are tribal as well. Then you evolve again into a species that controls the world, but other cities or continents on your starting planet are not under your control, so you must build land, sea and air vehicles to either kill, befriend or religeously brainwash each other to take control over the entire planet. After globalising your home planets spice collecting operation, your species will be unified and develop a space ship, and the game becomes a 4X in space, where you have to terraform and colonise the 500,000 planets in the Milkyway. Here, the game really becomes open ended, you collect the spice from your empires planets, and sell to others at a profit. You can find other empires, all of which use randomly generated species as well, and talk to them, forge an alliance with them, request help, declare war, even ask them to go to war with another empire for you. There are many upgrades you can find and buy for your ship, from being able to terraform the planet, to being able to blow it up entirely. The only nuisance is having to scroll the mousewheel to enter and exit a planet or solar system, which gets annoying since you will be doing it a lot.Also, the Galactic adventures are basically garbage. Your not missing out on much if you ignore there existance in the space stage. The planet editor that comes with it is fun to mess around with, but it's not really complex enough to create interesting and dynamic scenes, like the level editors of other games. It's cool how you can replay them after finishing them though by just flying back to the same planet.Also, the online doesn't work anymore, which means you can't share your creations with others online, or use or see theirs, which is a shame. But the game comes with something like 2000+ creations anyway, and you can still make your own.

												Gave a bad review for Spore, going to give another, different opinion on Galactic Adventures.Reinstalled it awhile ago so that when I had relatives (children) visiting they would have something to play that wasn't A) age inappropriate and B) wouldn't ask me questions or have me complete a stage/quest/enemy every five minutes.  I don't mind helping but when a kid is basically having you play the entire game for them, that game is not for them.  Said kids were absolutely delighted by Spore and I realized what my issue with it was in the first place.Simply put, this is a game that doesn't know who it's target audience is.  Or maybe I misinterpreted who it's demographic is and said hey, you can make stuff, this game is for me.Spore / Galactic Adventures, is, a great game for kids (with some exceptions)... It's cartoony, whimsical, and they can flex their imaginations with the creature creation.  However, there are a few principles that a very young child will have difficulty grasping.  My neighbor's kid (a seven year old) loved the tide pool and loved the animal stage but once he got to the civilization stage it went south real fast.  So maybe nine or ten is the ideal age here.That said, there is some absolute talent behind some of the player made creatures/vehicles etc and I'm going to take a guess that those folks are adults.  I had fun with the creation aspect of the game too.  This is where the game has it's identity crisis for me.  Some of it is appealing to adults, some of it is childish, but the whole of it appeals to neither at the same time.  Finally, the concept itself is a novel idea and one that I hope can be refined some day- in a different game.Once that novelty has worn off, all that's left is a tedious cycle of traveling between planets, trading spice (literally the only thing you get to trade), looking at butt ugly creatures my neighbor's kid made (sorry, kiddo!), running home to defend against raiders, and terraforming- things that sound exciting at first and are exciting at first, and then get promptly beaten with a tediousness stick.

												As sad as it is that Spore discontinued when there was quite the work that could be done to expand this even further, and as much as we all hate EA and their shetty ways with SecuROM and max-3-installs-per-CD-purchase to prevent privacy (which only managed to make actual buyers feel ripped) Spore was and is one of the most awesome simulation games ever made by EA along with the Sim-series (no not you SimCity idgaf bout you (jk I just haven't played it))Considering how EA Maxis "left the game to rot" back in 2011, the community still stands ongoing and strong, check the sporepedia and the sporums if in doubt, and that's partly what makes this so awesome - Spore in itself is a quite nice game, but with the GA expansion it took it all up a notch from a simple simulation-creature-creator game unto a whole new world where you can "create your own games and storylines" so to say, which is why I love this piece of goodness in my gameventory. I have had quite a few troubles with this, such as the robot packs DLC only being given out to people in the US making me weepweep a little, but after a 20 minute call to a foreign country because EA didn't care to make customer service in a shetty place as Denmark (I suppose I can understand that, but really) I finally got my free robotpack and all, because being an artist and a creative soul I need all the building blocks I can have to get the max out of this game. Usually these wouldn't be available for anyone who didn't get the code back in like 2011, so I'm pretty privileged to have an account from 2015 with the registered parts. WHICH IS TERRIBLE. This should be made free for all, and this is one of the few downsides to Spore. The technical issues within this game, due to the fight on pirates is initially what ruined a lot of it's potential.So it's a game you gotta take for what it is. There'll be no underwater stage, no female voice syncing no new patches and no cool new expansion packs in near (nor probably far) future, but at least the game has a hell of a lot of replayability, a lot of opportunities that relies on the player's creativity as well as opportunities for the player to make their own game within this game! It's gameception! I'd warmly suggest this for any person enjoying creative single-player simulation, exploring and adventuring.

												I played the hell outta this game as a kid, the base game part. But the Galactic adventures expansion pack really isn't worth your money. It's one giant dissapointment after the next. Let me preface this by saying I love the original spore! Even though it's a game designed for kids and is fairly simple I still think it's really fun. The GA exspansion pack basically allows you to beam down to planets (sort of), in reality you can only beam down to planets deemed adventure planets. If you played the original spore you would know that you get missions in the space stage and going to empires and requesting mission, then they tell you the background blah blah blah. Well in galactic adventures they just say "beam down on this planet" with no context what so ever! Also any of the regular planets you cannot beam to them. The adventures have potential, and I've seen alot of great remakes of areas from Bioshock and other games (how it works is you make buildings in the building creator and use them to look like walls, not only is this extremely tedious but you also end up having cities in the space stage being made entirely of walls or computers...really bad) but ultimatley there is nothing to do. The weapons are just like the creature stage in that they recharge with each use and there's only four viable ones (8 in total). The other thing is you can't swap weapons in game so making a "find this gun/tool to do that" type adventure is impossible. Long story short is if you want to see remakes of famous seens from video games just look up minecraft remakes, because this expansion spits in the face of the original game.

												This it not another review of unfulfilled promises, because I was VERY late to the party so I have no idea what those promises were supposed to BE.  I tried really hard to like this game, but it essentially punished me the entire time I was playing it.  I don't care that the multiplayer servers have been shut down, it's just not a very good game.  Never in my life have I seen a game that was centered totally on sandboxy crafting that simultaneously made it obnoxiously and irrationally difficult to do so.  Graphics are terrible, sounds are okay if you don't mind public domain animal noises.  The game is divided into five stages:  Cell, creature, tribal, civilization, and space.As a small organism you eat bits of meat, other creatures, or plant particles in order to increase your DNA.  You get bigger, break into a larger aquatic biome, and do it again.  This stage is actually very quick, unless you want to be an omnivore, in which case you need the ONE mouth part that enables that behavior, and spend some time grinding whatever you haven't been eating.  The creature stage by far takes the longest.  This is the major developmental stage for your creatures, and all the parts are earned here.  The stage is basically nests of neutral creatures, nests of creatures that attack on sight, giant creatures you have almost no hope of defeating, bones to pick DNA parts from, and fruit.  So you make friends with other species or eat them, and tweak your creature's physiology as this is your last chance to do so.Many of the creature parts are purely cosmetic.  The ones that actually raise stats may not play nice with the other parts in terms of clipping or alignment.  I assume every creature was made with the in-game editor, and that I must be terribly bad at it since all my creatures looked like walking potatoes.  Hell, the first two races I made weren't even upright, the game is actually somewhat terrible at telling you these things.  Side note:  who puts wings in a game like this and doesn't technically enable flying?  You flap, you glide.  Your AI pack members go higher than you - always, as if to mock you.  The game was designed this way.  What the ♥♥♥♥? The tribal stage consists of half a dozen major tribes that arise from the masses of creatures.  You're given roughly 12 buildings/techs/instruments with which to make friends or destroy your enemies.  Again.  The civilization stage you finally get a proper city.  You can eventually have land, air, and sea vehicles.  One of each type.  You can design four buildings, including the city hall.  That's it.  AI is predictable, it's not even Civilization Lite.  The space stage held lots of promises of being really deep and cool, but honestly I only made it there once. I read later that there wasn't actually a lot of content for this stage, they were hoping people would make the bulk of the missions for them.   The whole game is a disappointing slog.  My tally:  1st race:  Didn't know what I was doing.  Three hours into the game, it crashed.  I heard later that the game has a problem running on newer hardware.  Since Maxis FORGOT HOW TO PROGRAM AN AUTOSAVE, my entire race and progress was gone.  2nd race:  I created an omnivore.  Or tried.  I made it to the creature stage, discovered I wasn't getting any of the appropriate mouth-parts.  Checked online, learned that to become an omnivore you have to do this in the CELLULAR stage, or not at all.   3rd race:  I made the Krogan from Mass Effect.  Murdered everything in sight.  The civilization stage felt restrictive and obnoxiously difficult somehow, though dropping nukes was fun.  I actually made it to the space stage, and I got this feeling that there would be quite a bit more cool stuff if I wasn't slaughtering everything.  This restart's on me.4th race:  I made a true omnivore, got up to the creature stage.  Befriended everyone I could, enemies that attacked me became extinct.  Advanced to the tribal stage, discovered the game had classified me as a predator.  I'm sorry what?  So I reloaded, and spent the next TWO HOURS befriending THIRTY SPECIES, watching the same literal song and dance routines over.. and over.. and OVER again.  Advanced to the tribal stage, discovered I was now in the MIDDLE of the predator rating instead of buried in the deep end.  From this, I infer that I would have to spend another two hours and befriend another thirty species to touch "middle-road".  I don't even think that many species can be on the planet.  I've also read somewhere that the parts you have equipped may adversely affect your alignment, so literally the ONLY THING the game has going for it still works against you.  No thanks.

												This game, and its companion Galactic Adventures, are fantastic.   I cannot, however, recommend the game. The reason i cannot do so is because EA does not properly support this product, from what I can tell.   Upon installing and running the first time, I was prompted to connect to my EA account.  That was simple enough.  The problem, however, is that the servers which handled authentication apparently were shut off some time ago,so you can't properly authenticate the game.    You'll get an error saying the code doesn't work, and if you try to use the CD key, it will say it is not valid. I tried a workaround by logging into EA's site and binding the key there, but that also doesnt' work.   It says it successfully bound to the account but doesn't connect in Steam. Contact with EA support is what gave me the information I've stated above.   The only thing I haven't tried is downloading Origin (security holes from what I've seen, so no) and then using that to obtain Spore via my linked account, separating it from Steam. This game is entirely playable without registration, but there is no access to the creations of other players, which was a major benefit to Galactic Adventures (since it has a mission builder) as well as being able to reach new creatures for Spore that others created.  I would wager this will also cause problems with downloading DLC and entering codes to activate it, as seems to be a major complaint on forums regarding this game.   The workaround is to call EA support (not email or online chat) and bounce through extensions until you get to someone who can MANUALLY ADD YOUR KEY TO THE ACTIVATION DATABASE.   It's just not worth it.    I'm reminded now why this is still the most pirated video game in history as of 2014.

												Let me start off by saying I'm reviewing Galactic Adventures instead of regular Spore because I think Galactic Adventures provides the biggest experience, and it's pretty much the same thing as Spore but with the adventures. My opinion here can also be applied to normal Spore.God, do I love Spore. Waaaaay too much. It's one of my most favorite games of all time, but at the same time, it's brought hate and anger not only upon myself, but upon my close friends.I know, I need to explain. It would seem that it's an unfair judgment to say this is one of my favorite games considering I only have 33 hours logged on it and I've only had it for a few weeks (at the time I'm writing this review), but I've owned the CD-ROM version since it came out, and I'm pretty sure I've spent hundreds upon hundreds of hours playing it. As someone who's soon to be 16 and grew up with a different era of games, this is one of the biggest games to define my childhood (considering I was about 9 or 10 when it came out). I got addicted to it, and sadly, my friends did, too. Every single friend I've shown Spore to, they got addicted to it, and it became the center of every friendship I had. Sadly, Spore wasn't multiplayer, so I had to constantly watch my friends play Spore when they came over. They weren't open to anything else, just Spore. It became incredibly boring and repetitive, and because of that, many fights broke out between me and my friends, which made me just hate Spore all the more. But at the same time, I loved it. When my friends would leave, I'd have Spore all to myself, and I'd play it constantly until another friend comes over and the cycle repeats. Sadly, I eventually lost my Spore CD, and for the longest time, I was at peace with my friends. We would actually do things together.That is, until, Spore went on sale a few weeks ago. I remembered loving that game, so I bought it again, hoping my friends forgot about it. I logged into my old Spore account, and surely enough, everything was still there. It was all coming back to me; I couldn't help but shed a tear when I saw my old creations, my childhood. I was a little irritated when playing my old adventures since I was terrible at making them, not to mention I was terrible at spelling, but I saw it more as a joke than something to be embarrassed about. After looking over some old creations, I started a new game on the story mode, and I was instantly hooked again.And eventually, my friends got hooked again. They saw me playing it, they started playing it again, and I even have some new friends hooked to it. I thought the cycle stopped when I lost the Spore disc, but a cycle can never stop, it always repeats. As of this week, I got into a small argument with my friend over how we should do something else other than Spore, which made me realize this whole thing is getting worse. But at the same time, Spore is more fun than ever. It's the best game ever, it's the worst game ever.But enough of what I believe makes it so great. From a non-personal standpoint, this game's still something to be enjoyed. The story mode has five stages to it, and each one is unique, which gives it a fresh experience. Each stage is fairly short, but replayable. Not to mention, a bigger variety of choices opens up when you chose to be friendly, neutral, or aggressive in each stage. It changes not only the way you play and the abilities you're given, but also what other think of you, so planning out your choices is necessary. Plus, the fact that you create the creature you play as is really cool. All of the possibilities makes each time you play story mode seem like a unique experience. Outside of creatures, you can also build vehicles, houses, and my favorite, adventures. Playing the adventures was a huge part of my experience playing Spore, and making them was just as fun.It's pretty hard to look at Spore from a critical standpoint, because for me, there's not too much to say outside of the fact that what it does is really fun. It defined my childhood, and because of that, I've chosen to give it two different reviews: my own personal review, and a review from a critical standpoint.From a critical standpoint, I would give Spore a 9 out of 10, and I would recommend it to anyone who's a fan of games that offer a creative, unique experience.However, from a personal standpoint, I would give Spore a perfect 10 out of 10. I just hold it too close to my heart, and I've played it way too much to think it's not perfect.

												A beautiful concept with a slight grasp of science and evolution. The base game is already amazing. 												Spore Galactic Adventures is Spore's expansion pack. If you've played Spore, then you would know that you evolved on a homeworld to a space faring empire. The adventure editor lets you create your own adventure. This powerful tool can let you create you own game. You could recreate the Hunger Games or Star Wars. You could even create something new like a castle attack or something. Creativity is the limit. When you finish your adventure, you can publish it so others can see and play it. 												Spore Galactic Adventures is Spore's expansion pack. If you've played Spore, then you would know that you evolved on a homeworld to a space faring empire. The captain editor is an outfitter similer to the others. You can put newly unlocked gear on your captain. Each item has a unique ability that is useful when you're doing adventures on planets. The adventure editor lets you create your own adventure. This powerful tool can let you create you own game. You could recreate the Hunger Games or Star Wars. You could even create something new like a castle attack or something. Creativity is the limit. When you finish your adventure, you can publish it so others can see and play it. This add on is very enjoyable, though it has a few bugs, they're nothing that can ruin your experience. I would recomend you get this if you don't have it. You would not be dissapointed.

												May be scientifically innacurate regarding evolution theory, but being able to play and evolve a creature on the path to space is very enjoyable. Starting out as a microscopic organism and evolving your way towards intelligence, all the while developing your species the way you want: an insect, a bird, a reptile, or a totally bizarre hybrid of 2 or more different animal types, say, a giant spider-like creature with a shark mouth and bird wings.Although the gameplay may not be very spectacular, being able to create almost any creature, building, vehicle, and spaceship your mind can possibly conceive is the truly greatest part of Spore. Spore's online functions no longer work, But i personally think it's much better to play Spore without downloading User Generated Content. Especially since default/Maxis creations often always look so much better than user made content, which a great majority are usually just a random mess of parts, horrible-looking/poorly-made creatures, giant♥♥♥♥♥♥♥monsters, creatures with massively oversized (and sometimes spikey) genitalia, or OP creatures with all possible stats at maximum.

 1. My Opinion  I really love this game, in fact, I've been playing spore ever since it came out! When Galactic adventures came out, I was really excited to see what its all about. I've only had it for about 3 days and  I have 22.8 hours. Which I think shows how addicting this game is.  2. The good stuff about it (Still My Opinion)  What I really love about this game is that you can create a creature that has endless oppurtunities! There are some codes you can type in by doing ctrl + L. Shift + C and then type in a code such as adddna (which adds dna/money, of course) and freedom (only works in creature creator outside of world) 2.1. This Add on With the Galactic Adventure Add on it really adds a lot, it adds a new captain creator (where you add accesories to your creature/captain.) What I was amazed by is the Adventure Creator. Basically what the Adventure Creator is, it's a creator where you make a world by landscaping it, terraforming it, and adding trees and stuff (And boy do these trees make you feel like your on an alien planet with a drug trip.) and then later you put creatures from Maxis, the internet, or your own on the world with houses or whatever, basically you can do what ever you want in the Adventure Creator. 3. The not so good stuff /glitchesSome of the bad stuff about this game, well, aren't actually that bad, except one. If you complete the cell stage (the first stage) you go into the creature stage, but the problem is, when your on the galaxy and you want to start at, well, the creature stage or tribal stage, it doesn't work. What im saying is it will say "Must complete cell stage" or _____ stage, even when you have completed that stage, I dont know if thats just my game or whatever. Now on to the other bad thing (This is only if you have a Spore account.) If you click "Keep me signed in" it will keep you signed in... For that session, and so the  next time you play Spore, it logs you out. I may just be lazy but it would be nice if it would actually keep you logged in. 4. my opinion... again Your probably tired of reading my grammatically incorrect, misspelled review, but this is the end of it. But I think that the Galactic Adventures pack really does make Spore a lot more fun. It gives the game a lot more story and fun stuff to do. But one thing I do wish, is that they add more Maxis made galactic adventure levels. Currently there is only about 6 levels, and if you don't have a Spore Account, thats the only Galactic adventures levels your gonna get. 5. The end, again I have a mixed review about this, but im gonna give it a 9/10 and a yes to recommending this game, and literally only because i've played this game in my childhood and am obsessed with this game.Bye!
